issues.title: Consider section on acceptable usage scenarios?
issues.author: cipherboy
issues.body:
The introduction currently contains broad language around the desirable properties of these category of algorithms:

> Their theoretic security is well understood and depends only on the security of the underlying hash function.  As such, they can serve as an important building block for quantum-resistant information and communication technology.

I think it'd benefit the broader community (especially, protocol authors looking at adding PQC into their protocols) if some of this latter phrase ("_important building block_") could be expanded upon, perhaps enumerating some scenarios in which these trade offs are acceptable.

E.g., perhaps in the scenario where potential theoretical weakness in the design of SLH-DSA or ML-DSA are an unacceptable risk to an organization (but still desires PQC security), S-HBS schemes could be considered?

comments.author: thomwiggers
comments.body:
This is something that we should have a discussion about. I think that it might make sense that we recommend some evaluation criteria even, i.e., S-HBS might be appropriate IF you can't use SLH-DSA, ML-DSA, can predict the number of signatures before hand, ...

>E.g., perhaps in the scenario where potential theoretical weakness in the design of SLH-DSA 

Just quickly noting that SPHINCS+ is basically an improved XMSS (in more ways than state) (in fact, XMSS even included in the SPHINCS+ specification!), so any attack that applies to SLH-DSA will likely apply to XMSS.

comments.author: cipherboy
comments.body:
> Just quickly noting that SPHINCS+ is basically an improved XMSS (in more ways than state) (in fact, XMSS even included in the SPHINCS+ specification!), so any attack that applies to SLH-DSA will likely apply to XMSS.

Ahhh, yes, this is true. I think that then strengthens the question, in what scenarios _would_ you prefer this set of algorithms? :-) 

E.g., in what scenario would you be able to use S-HBS, if you can't use SLH-DSA? The parties had the former available but not the latter due to (artificially) constrained supply of algorithms? 

Ephemeral signing keys (like with [sigstore](https://docs.sigstore.dev/signing/overview/)) would perhaps be one valid use case under that scenario (artificially restricted algorithms)... _with the caveat_ that ML-DSA would likely still be more performant and overall better, assuming resources to support both were present.

issues.title: Devices with degrading storage
issues.author: thomwiggers
issues.body:
Stefan-Lukas Gazdag wrote:

> Storages are discussed/shown including CDs and USB drives, but what about smartcards? Do you consider them out of scope (and maybe unsuitable for practical use) or do you view them as some kind of HSM? Because smartcards have quite some restrictions on their own and this may be true for other use cases. The RAM is limited and the non-volatile memory wears of. So you need to think about state and memory management. Also see Andreas Hülsing's paper from 2018. At genua we tested JavaCards at some point with similar experiences. A full discussion would be over the top for the Internet-Draft, but you may want to add a note on this.

comments.author: thomwiggers
comments.body: The paragraph in which USB and CD memory is mentioned refers to "external storage" while I think that the devices that Stefan-Lukas is referring would be those that run the signing algorithm (as that would trigger the continued write operations to flash). The point is very valid — but I don't think it's worth adding a new paragraph to the document about.

issues.title: Elaborating in operational considerations?
issues.author: thomwiggers
issues.body:
Stefan-Lukas Gazdag wrote:

> - Operational considerations: A few years ago I took some thought on operating systems and how to make sure there's no copies of the state or old keys left. My conclusion was that you need your whole system to be secure at some point in time because you won't be able to handle all the temporary copies within a modern computer. For examples caches are hell. There quite a few of them. Data stored there is only really written to where it should go if being flushed. You do not necessarily want to flush. You're slowing down the whole system and sometimes things may go wrong. Or your OS just decides that what you want is not what the OS wants. You can't just read a recently written key supposedly written to disk to make sure it's stored, because there may be just some cache (maybe even on the hard disk before the actual write operation on the disk). Sometimes you have to trust that everything's alright or it will get messy.


I think the point of this is basically: should we elaborate on the design requirements/environment requirements for secure operations at the OS level?

comments.author: thomwiggers
comments.body: The operational considerations section is mainly about "soft" requirements (procedures, training, operators) rather than technical requirements. I think that this probably makes sense to keep that way. The "Requirements for secure state management" paragraph that follows it is probably a better spot for this — but I think that this is essentially already covered there and by `[MCGREW]`.

issues.title: Interval-based approaches
issues.author: thomwiggers
issues.body:
Stefan-Lukas Gazdag wrote:

> - You can advance the state / key and store it before signing, even for an intervall of keys. E. g. reserve interval u (let's say 100 OTS keys) and store a key before signing where you got rid of all OTS keys that are reserved (forgetting old keys) or advance a PRNG to the seed you need. Which leads to another point:
>
> - What about giving up on OTS keys? Using each OTS signing key is only important if you want to proof, that you possess a signature for each OTS key. But  e. g. for the interval approach you could just sacrifice / omit a few (contradicts the last part of chapter four in the Internet-Draft, I think). Imagine the interval in the last point: Your advanced key was written successfully, you start using the OTS keys from the interval that are only stored in volatile memory and suddenly there's a blackout. You restart the system. Worst-case, all keys of your reserved intervall are gone. Bad, but should happen seldomly.

I don't think that this erases all of the state-keeping concerns, but it certainly seems viable as a defense-in-depth approach.  This does mean that you need to increase the size of the tree (potentially significantly) which may erase some of the benefits of stateful hbs.

issues.title: "Soft-fail" / Warnings when at a certain amount of signatures left
issues.author: thomwiggers
issues.body:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/pqc/eZw6BfguNtNPDU2A1xURVP7_4DY/

Alexander Reilean wrote:

> While reviewing draft-ietf-pquip-hbs-state I understand that it addresses prevention of state reuse, backup management and training operators, but I think it leaves a gap when it comes to warning users before they exhaust the available signatures. People can still drive themselves into a corner if they follow the prescribed procedures.
>  
>  
> Consider a system configured for N=100 signatures. When attempting the N+1 signature, the system returns a “signatures exhausted” error. While this prevents a disaster, the users are already in an operational dead-end because there is no graceful recovery path. Would it be helpful if the system could optionally warn about this a couple of signatures earlier?
>  
> I propose extending section 3:
>  
> ```
> Consider providing a configurable warning threshold (M), that is triggered when M signatures remain. When the threshold is reached, the system should return a `signatures nearing exhaustion` error, requiring the user to explicitly acknowledge it in a way that cannot be trivially skipped.
>  
> This “soft fail” condition directs attention to the approaching exhaustion while signatures are still available, allowing enough time to initiate key rotation before operations are disrupted.
>  
> For flexibility, implementations may allow setting the threshold to M=0 to disable this feature.
> ```
>  
>  
> The draft could also recommend the layer at which the check should occur, e.g., in the HSM, in the software that uses the HSM, or be a part of a checklist that humans run through. Without explicitly recommending who ought to do it, we might end up in a situation where everyone thought it was someone else’s responsibility. I believe this should happen in the lowest possible layer, so the warning cannot be bypassed by higher-level applications.
>  
> Acknowledging this error could be done by setting a configuration parameter or sending a special command to the system. It has to be an action that goes beyond a typical yes/continue/ok that people go through absent-mindedly.
>  
> The “soft fail” feature is meant to be a “constructive annoyance” – it creates a temporary disruption in order to avoid a catastrophic one.
>  
>  
> Would others find this addition valuable to the draft?
>
>p.s. the suggestion is not rooted in experience with running HSMs or secure rooms where these things happen, but rather on a hunch and a background in usability. I'd be particularly interested in hearing from those with operational experience whether they've faced such issues and how they've addressed them.

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/pqc/eZw6BfguNtNPDU2A1xURVP7_4DY/

comments.author: thomwiggers
comments.body: We will add a few sentences to operational considerations about availability that you may want some kind of warning system if you reach certain thresholds of signatures left.

comments.body: Thanks for incorporating my feedback; the proposed wording sounds good to me.

issues.title: Clarify how we differ from ETSI TR 103 692 "State management for stateful authentication mechanisms"
issues.author: fluppe2
issues.body:
At IETF 123 PQUIP session the question came up, what the draft adds considering ETSI TR 103 692 "State management for stateful authentication mechanisms" (https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_tr/103600_103699/103692/01.01.01_60/tr_103692v010101p.pdf).

Clarify this in the introductory sections of the draft.

Punchline: ETSI's doc is more focused on background information, comparison of HSS/LMS and XMSS(^MT) and making aware of the issues coming up when having a state. Backup and restore management is not explored (see section 6.2: "It is possible that secure mechanisms for back-up and restore for S-HBS schemes can be developed, or that there are specific contexts or applications wherein secure back-up and restore can be achieved. Such situations and solutions are not explored in the present document").

issues.title: Clarify that private key and state can be separated
issues.author: thomwiggers
issues.body:
From Scott Fluhrer's comments:

> You might want to make it clearer that the private key can be effectively split up into two parts: the private key, that is, the recipe for generating one-time-signature private keys (e.g. the private seed for XMSS), and the state (which tells you which one-time-signature to use next).  Those two halves could be handled independently.  That is, the first part is stateless, that is, it can be handled just like any other private key, and we can focus in on the dynamically updated second part (the state).

I might want to add to this that there is a funny thing going on where the private key mainly has confidentiality requirements whereas the state has, somewhat uniquely, stricter integrity requirements on whatever storage mechanism, which is also somewhat different from the usual things we expect when handling keys.

issues.title: Should we expand "when appropriate"
issues.author: thomwiggers
issues.body:
Scott suggested the following elaboration:

> Section 1.1 When are S-HBS appropriate – one thing that is not listed is that the verification code can be quite simple (hash computation plus some simple logic) – this may be an advantage for tightly constrained verifiers.

I would argue that this is covered by “performance of alternatives being prohibitive” — but I am also trying to keep the “when are they appropriate” section as short, sweet and to the point as possible. We can consider expanding on this section a bit more, if people would want to see that (especially if they have unanswered questions or see gaps).

comments.author: thomwiggers
comments.body: we will split performance in implementation size and run time and call it a day

issues.title: Differing keys in sectorization
issues.author: thomwiggers
issues.body:
Scott Fluhrer suggested:

> In section 5.3, you mention the possibility of using different private seeds (XMSS terminology) for different sectors.  Normally in cryptography, we suggest using different keys to reduce the amount of damage that is done if a key is leaked.  However, that doesn’t apply here – here, if any private seed leaks, the adversary can sign anything they want (and while they may be limited to that specific sector, the adversary can still sign at will, given that there is no standard mechanisms to revoke signatures from a sector).  I would suggest using the same private seed for all sectors (unless it is significantly more convenient to not to) – it may make things simpler, and is no less secure.

I may be missing some point why this makes sense to do so I'm creating this issue — I agree that we should clarify or indeed simplify the sectorization (and probably note why there's no point to different keys though it is possible).

comments.author: fluppe2
comments.body:
I think we explain in section 5.3 how sectorization can be seen as a state management strategy. That is,

> As a result, system operators MAY distribute sectors to multiple cryptographic devices, allowing for performance scaling, and resiliency/availability, while only requiring them to manage the uniqueness of each sector instead of having to co-ordinate state usage between devices since in this scenario a sector cannot generate signatures from another sector's signature space.

Of course, this does not address OTS key reuse within sectors, but that is not the point here. The aim is isolation for damage containment and operational robustness, while also supporting scalability.

However, we should sharpen that paragraph, see corresponding PR.

issues.title: Scope: speeding up signing?
issues.author: thomwiggers
issues.body:
Scott Fluhrer helpfully suggested providing text for speeding up signing: 

> One thing I’m not sure about: there are some clever ways to speed up the signing process (by storing some of the intermediate nodes of the Merkle tree, and use those nodes to help generate the authentication path), and that may interact with the state management.  I know of four such techniques, each of which is “best” by some criteria, and some of which update which nodes are stored during each signature, and one which does not (which ends up using more storage and require more hashes to sign, but also avoid issues with updating the nodes along with the state).  To what extent should this draft address this?  I should be the one to contribute text, should you decide it should be appropriate (although I would like some guidelines as to how thorough I should be – I could go one for quite some time…)

The question is do we think this fits in scope? It may be a bit too "implementation" side

comments.author: fluppe2
comments.body:
I must confess that it sounds extremely interesting, and I would be very happy to include a reference to a paper describing such optimizations.

However, optimizing signature generation for stateful hash-based schemes may not be a top priority in the typical (offline) use cases envisioned for such schemes, such as Root CAs or Code Signing. Therefore, in my opinion, this is out of scope for the document, as it would require a deep dive into such optimizations and could lead to diffusion rather than providing clear guidance.

I support the suggested close of this issue.

issues.title: Scope: parameter selection
issues.author: thomwiggers
issues.body:
Scott Fluhrer suggested that we could include more content on "how to do HBS signatures".

> I’m not sure to what extent we want to broaden this from “how we do state management” to “general advice on how to use stateful hash-based signatures”; although the document does have some of that general advice.  If we continue in that vein, I believe that you should mention that in XMSS/XMSS^MT, RFC 8391 and NIST SP 800-208 differs on SHAKE-based parameter sets.  I would recommend using the NIST parameter sets, should you decide you need an XMSS+SHAKE parameter set (the SHAKE-128 parameter set that RFC 8391 uses with n=32 reduces security to 128 bits, which is significantly weaker than the design goal).
>
>Another thought (if we were continuing with the giving general advice about stateful hash based signatures) is on selecting the parameter set.  For example, LMS with “w=8” (which would be w=256 in XMSS terminology) approximately halves the signature size, at the cost of making the signature generation and verification processes more expensive.  How far should we go into that (given that it is covered by other documents)

I feel that "picking parameters" is a bit more of an operator concern and we do already touch on that (for example in that you need to consider your state management solutions when picking parameters). So this might be worth following up on?

comments.author: thomwiggers
comments.body: We're currently thinking about making a passing comment that size/speed may matter and you need to think about this in the operational considerations, but don't go into lots of detail.

comments.author: thomwiggers
comments.body: ah we should still ask for feedback on this to the list

issues.title: Falkos review during WGLC
issues.author: fluppe2
issues.body:
See:

- https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/pqc/BDAo2GCOe73vHK2AZYHYRFYKEOU/
- https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/pqc/R8FJ485gWAOgXVb7xqOKnudF4y0/

Tasks:

- [x] (T1) Section 2.1.1. Privat Key Components

  - is lacking an introductionary sentence, it starts with an itemize right away.

  - ” the private key is a static secret”. It should be mentioned that this is only a conceptional view. In actual implementations, the state of the OTS generator may well change with each signature.

- [x] (T2) Section 2.1.2. State Management

  - “to securely update the state after each signature,” This sentence could be read as describing an insecure state update and should be changed to definitely describing a secure state update.

  - “such as, e.g.,” language: seems to redundantly introduce the example

  - “puncturable schemes [BSW16],” This technology is not properly introduced in the draft. It should also be made clear whether this references a deployable technology or research that in the future might become deployable technology. Further, I suggest it should be at least outlined how this concept relates to SHBS and the prescriptions of this draft or left completely aside.

- [x] (T3) Section 3. Operational Considerations

  * A paragraph in this section states “In addition to the state management, implementers MAY consider to implement mechanisms to prevent abrupt signature exhaustion” and then “This warning condition SHOULD require explicit acknowledgment from the user”. I’d say that the “SHOULD” is inappropriate since the whole mechanism is under “MAY”. I couldn’t figure out what I should understand from this “SHOULD” if I am anyway free to not implement said mechanism of not, due to the “MAY”. So I would prefer to change the “SHOULD” to “MAY” as well.

- [x] (T4) Section 4. Requirements for Secure State Management

  *  “Atomicity: each operation must be indivisible — either the signature is generated and the state is updated together, or neither
    occurs.” I see that it is necessary to prevent the release of a signature without state update, but I don’t see why it would be necessary to prevent state update without releasing a signature. I claim that “signature is generated” is not an appropriate concept in any case. Even if the device would internally generate a signature together atomically with the state update, that would not be observable on the outside. If the device is reset after the generation, the state update would persist (as it has to for the operation to be secure) but the signature would be lost before it can be output. I think this statement should be rendered to appropriately describe observable behaviour of the system and thus effectively require state update before signature release and not more.

  * “The main concerns here are […] how an accidental/intentional failure/glitch might affect the state security, and cloning.” I don’t understand the final part of the sentence “and cloning”. What is meant exactly how “cloning” is affected? What kind of cloning is considered here?

- [x] (T5) Section 5.2. Distributed Multi-trees (SP-800-208)

  * “The [SP-800-208]” – remove “The” (multiple instances)

- [x] (T6) Section 5.4. Key/State Transfer

  * Please explain what “strong synchronization” is exactly defining, specifically what the word “strong” adds to bare “synchronization”.

- [x] (T7) Section 5.6. Variable-length Signature Chains

  * I don’t understand the conclusion about variable length chains given in this section. Is there a way to realize a cryptographic sound solution? If yes, please describe, reference, or outline it. If not, the text should say so explicitly.

  * In my view the explanation given in this section starting with “From an operational perspective, the ability of a subordinate tree to sign 
either messages or new subordinate trees leads to severe security implications […]” is not adequate as it doesn’t clearly answer this 
essential question.

- [x] (T8) Section 7. Security Considerations

  * The text in this section should state that security considerations are given throughout the document.

- [x] (T9) General (and in particular Section 2.1.2., 5.6.)

  * After giving it some more thought, I have general concerns about addressing non-standard cryptographic schemes in this draft. Besides the above topic, this also applies to the reference [BSW16]. My suggestion would be to remove these two references (and others if I should have overlooked them) to research topics or non-standard cryptographic schemes. If the authors consider mentioning these reference as necessary for some reason, that should be done by clearly pointing out that those topics are addressed as potential future technologies. However, I would still have concerns in this case, as it seems impossible to predict how currently non-standard cryptographic ideas might end up as standards. I do not see how the reader of this draft will benefit from such vague references to potential future technologies. I rather see the risk of mismatches, wrong interpretations, and the unintentional facilitation of justifications of the use of non-standard cryptographic schemes.

comments.body:
Task (T1):

pulls.title: Address feedback from Russ Housley: No longer use BCP 14 language
pulls.author: thomwiggers
pulls.body:
We were using the BCP 14 boilerplate basically because it was in the IETF  template.  

This PR removes it, though I will note that nobody so far noted it. I honestly don't know what the exact cutoff is. RFC 2119, section 6, says it MUST only be used for interoperability hazards, so I guess that supports that BCP14 keywords do not apply here (most of our uses are security concerns).

pulls.title: Remove XKCDs about time and programmers
pulls.author: thomwiggers
pulls.body:
Russ Housley acknowledges that they are funny argues that perhaps these are not appropriate to use as informal references in an XKCD. 

I do think they're funny. They've certainly been useful in e.g. slides in the discussions leading up to this moment. 
But perhaps the time has come for them to disappear from this document. 

Please voice opinions for or against in this PR or on list.

reviews.author: crypto4a
reviews.body:
I'm sad to see it go, but I think Russ is right.
That being said, we should definitely continue to use XKCD as much as possible in presentations and the like as a little irreverence can go a long way to help explain/motivate design choices! ;-)

reviews.author: BashiriK
reviews.body: I agree that it is time to say good by to the comics. At least we know that the wisdom they echoed is still inside.
